review.title: Correlation-based Intrinsic Evaluation of Word Vector Representations
review.abstract: We introduce QVEC-CCA--an intrinsic evaluation metric for word vector representations based on correlations of learned vectors with features extracted from linguistic resources. We show that QVEC-CCA scores are an effective proxy for a range of extrinsic semantic and syntactic tasks. We also show that the proposed evaluation obtains higher and more consistent correlations with downstream tasks, compared to existing approaches to intrinsic evaluation of word vectors that are based on word similarity.

sections.heading: 3 Linguistic Dimension Word Vectors
sections.text: Both QVEC and QVEC-CCA rely on a matrix of linguistic properties constructed from a manually generated linguistic resource. Linguistic resources are invaluable because they capture generalizations from domain experts. However, resource construction is expensive, so it is not always possible to find an existing resource that captures exactly the set of optimal lexical properties for a downstream task. Resources that capture more coarse-grained, general properties can be used instead, e.g. WordNet for semantic evaluation (Fellbaum, 1998) or Penn Treebank (Marcus et al., 1993, PTB) for syntactical evaluation. Since these properties do not exactly match the task, the intrinsic evaluation tests for a necessary (but possibly insufficient) set of generalizations (Pellbaum, 1998) or Penn Treebank (Marcus et al., 1993, PTB) for syntactical evaluation of panners can be used.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: We have introduced QVEC-CCA - an approach to intrinsic evaluation of word embedding. We have also shown that both QVEC and QVEC-CCA are not limited to semantic evaluation, but are general approaches to evaluate word vector contents in terms of desired linguistic properties. Semantic and syntactic linguistic characteristics that we use to construct linguistic dimension matrices are rather crude, so the proposed evaluation may approximate a number of downstream tasks, but may not be sufficient to evaluate fine-grained characteristics. In future work, we propose to find existing semantic, syntactic, morphological and typological resources (e.g. universal dependencies Treebank (Agic ́ et al., 2015) and WALS (Dryer and Haspelmath, 2013), as well as multilingual resources (e.g. Danish Supersenses (Martínez et al., 2015) to make better use of additional matececececal resources.
